name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: In honor of #SunshineWeek, it's time for our annual review of the previous year's stats on public records appeals.  2021 was our busiest year yet. Our Public Records Division opened and closed a record number of cases.  More stats:  https://t.co/EEO2M0ZoUh  https://t.co/1UPISi9h4J

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @OrffSteve The Department of Unemployment Assistance is under the office of the Secretary of Labor & Workforce Development, who is appointed by the Governor. You may also want to reach out to your state rep or state senator to see if their staff can assist you with the agency.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Our Tours Division is so excited to welcome visitors back to the State House and show you around our beautiful building.  If you'd like to schedule a free tour of the State House for your group, give us a call at 617-727-3676.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @nikolaidis Apologies, we didn't realize you were talking about an LLC. That fee is actually set by law, so the Secretary of Admin & Finance isn't allowed to lower it to offset the cost of the electronic payment fee. We need the Legislature to change the law in order to do that.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @nikolaidis For instance, the filing fee for certain annual reports is $125 on paper vs. $100 plus a $20 electronic payment fee for electronic filing. A little complicated due to the fee schedule, but still cheaper.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @nikolaidis Our fee schedule is set by regulations from the Secretary of Admin & Finance. That fee covers the cost of electronic payment, but we worked with A&F to offset the cost by making the filing fee lower for electronic filings. So you still save at least $5 by filing electronically.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: We are finally able to offer indoor tours of the State House again!  Tours are currently offered by appointment only. Call 617-727-3676 to book your tour.  https://t.co/RkfUA4q3uM

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @perrault777 That temporary law expired after the 2020 election, but we expect (and hope) that if the Legislature passes a new Vote by Mail law this year, it will allow our election officials to publicly remove & tabulate ballots in advance of Election Day permanently.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @perrault777 This website is incorrect about what our procedures were in 2020. Local election officials had the choice to remove ballots from envelopes and/or tabulate them before Election Day.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @kenmartinboston @RachelMiselman There's nothing in state law allowing recall elections, but many cities and towns have charter provisions or special acts allowing them for local offices. Boston's own charter would dictate whether their officials can be recalled.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: "This is the most powerful office in Massachusetts doing public business and dealing with public policy. The idea that the most powerful position in the state and its records are not subject to public scrutiny is absurd.‚Äù Secretary Galvin told the @BostonGlobe about his proposal.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Under current state law, the records of the Governor's office have been withheld from members of the public who requested them. Today, Secretary Galvin is proposing a bill to change that.   https://t.co/92oWwiDzdH

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @IfiCiSay @boston25 @townofmiltonma We certainly aren't saying that all abatements will be approved, but if you do plan to apply and/or appeal, you need to apply by today. Appeals are heard by the state Appellate Tax Board, but they can only hear appeals if the application and payment was timely.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: If you're filing for a property tax abatement, remember to get your application to your local assessors by tomorrow. Feb 1 is the deadline in most communities.  https://t.co/dHH0UvQDkf

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @IfiCiSay @boston25 @townofmiltonma Have you tried appealing? It's important to apply by the Feb. 1 deadline to preserve your right to an appeal.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @StevenL57  https://t.co/WcfqSpRhtQ

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: As chief election official in Massachusetts, Secretary Galvin strongly supports Election Day Registration. He wrote to members of the Legislature today to express his support and to urge them to guarantee voting by mail in all elections.  https://t.co/kEbANr2lI2

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: The deadline to file for property tax abatements in most cities and towns is just a few days away, on Feb 1.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin spoke with @GlobeOpinion about the need to pass an election reform bill soon, and his hope that the bill will allow Election Day registration.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: The deadline to apply for a property tax abatement is Feb. 1 in most communities.   Check out this helpful article & the list of abatement tips compiled by our Citizens' Information Service.  https://t.co/QUMeiQlWWi

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: One of our Registers of Deeds, @DickHowe, spoke with @WBUR recently about the work to find and remove racist covenants on old property records in Massachusetts.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: For those of you eager to apply for 2022 mail-in ballots, Secretary Galvin is hopeful we will see movement in the Legislature this coming week on a permanent vote by mail option & Election Day registration!  Stay tuned for updates on our election reform proposals.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Good news! We're one step closer to setting the 2022 state primary date for the 1st Tuesday in September.  Secretary Galvin pushed for this primary date so that November mail-in ballots will be ready as early as possible, and voters will have plenty of time to return them.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @ParkerHereford @marla_justmarla @seroxbury @CityOfBoston @BillGalvin4MA You're not required to have a physical residence in order to vote. You may register wherever you most often sleep at night. If you have a non-traditional residence without an address, you can draw the location of that residence on the map provided on the registration form.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin is speaking out about threats and intimidation aimed at election officials around the country, and calling for increased protections for the career local election officials and volunteer poll workers who keep our democratic system running.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Before lighting the lanterns at Old North Church last night, Secretary Galvin issued a statement calling for the protection of election workers from threats and intimidation as they carry out their duties.  https://t.co/S96cCC7pzs

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Last night, Secretary Galvin joined members of the clergy at @OldNorth1723 to light the church's famed lanterns, in a solemn remembrance of the attack on vote counting that took place at the U.S. Capitol 1 year ago.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Exhibits include documents from Shay's Rebellion & the 1820 Massachusetts Constitutional Convention, and an 1857 law allowing the Secretary to grant certificates of citizenship to Black residents after the Dred Scott decision.  Admission & parking at the museum is always free.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Today, our Commonwealth Museum opened a special exhibit: "Massachusetts Defending Democracy." The exhibit showcases historic documents from times Massachusetts expanded or defended voting rights and elected government.  https://t.co/Ky7b45Oppt

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: When they weren't performing, these Maynard High students got to talk to their state rep, @repkatehogan, and got an outdoor tour of the State House from one of our tour guides.  They also made friends with an audience member, a dog named Fiona.  https://t.co/QnFIuEjIok

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: In honor of the lost service members whose pictures are hung on the Gold Star Tree behind them, the Maynard High students performed Silent Night.  https://t.co/1mwHQk7JmF

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: It was wonderful having the Madrigal Singers of Maynard High School join us at the State House today. The school has been sending their talented singers to perform at the State House for 24 years!  https://t.co/YQ8wq66y6n

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin had a great time talking to (and taking selfies with) all of our student performers today. Especially the young man who asked what our most important right is. "The right to vote!"  https://t.co/6sbSN7e4cg

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: These very talented Sudbury students brought some cheer to the outside of the State House.  https://t.co/X6VK68twvN

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: It was wonderful having Ephraim Curtis Middle School students bring music back to the State House today. Their school has been performing in the State House Holiday Concert Series for more than 30 years!  https://t.co/FNw52zb1Gu

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Set-up is underway for a return to tradition at the State House.  At 10:30am, we will hold our first State House Holiday Concert since 2019, performed by the students of Sudbury's Ephraim Curtis Middle School. Feel free to stop by!  https://t.co/uOlMNVh2RZ

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: With the legislative session ending this week, time is running out to update our voting laws before the 2022 elections.  Sec. Galvin is asking the Legislature to extend temporary vote by mail laws again, while we wait for them to pass something permanent.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin is speaking about tomorrow's city elections. He is reminding voters it is too late to mail ballots at this point. Use a drop box or vote in person before polls close tomorrow.  https://t.co/t3IlXInGcW

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @kenmartinboston @BillGalvin4MA @CityOfBoston Voters are permitted to bring notes or informational materials with them to help them mark their ballots. They must take those notes with them when they leave.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @F_Zamborlini Finally, note that any notices were sent to voters in the same languages as their ballots.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @F_Zamborlini Of course, we're happy to mail an application to anyone who requests one, but voters don't need to fill out a form to get a ballot. Any written request with a signature, like a letter, is enough to request a ballot. You can even send an image of it to your city clerk by email.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @F_Zamborlini Unfortunately, since the law extending voting by mail was just passed in the last couple of weeks, there was not the time and funding available to send applications to all voters with upcoming elections. An online application is also not currently allowed by law.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: New census numbers show the population shifts in Massachusetts that will need to be taken into account during the upcoming redistricting process.  Detailed maps & data will be posted at  https://t.co/EwpUXzB5V8 next week.  Map courtesy of @UMASSDonahue .  https://t.co/D8lCw5VnYq

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin is announcing census numbers for cities in Massachusetts now. We now have 9 cities over 100k residents & our 2nd largest city, Worcester is over 200k for the first time.  https://t.co/xwYdX0Sy5a

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Our data analysts are hard at work going through the official 2020 Census numbers. Secretary Galvin will be able to announce detailed numbers for many of our communities later today.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Big redistricting news! After a long wait, we'll be getting official 2020 Census numbers to use for drawing voting districts 4 days earlier than expected.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: The mail-in & early voting laws that were in place in 2020 expired on June 30. Secretary Galvin has asked the Legislature to make those laws permanent.  Keep an eye on  https://t.co/zpA9cYmllw for updates on changes and info on absentee ballots.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin spoke to @GlobeOpinion about the urgent need to finalize mail-in & early voting laws for this fall's city elections, particularly in Boston.  ‚ÄúThe city needs the time to prepare to do vote-by-mail adequately."

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Stop by the State House today to get a free flag and, if you'd like one, a free guided tour of the historic State House grounds.  https://t.co/EXP750yCqT

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: To mark celebrate Independence Day, our State House Tours staff will be on Beacon St. today & tomorrow handing out flags and giving tours. Stop by from 10:30-3!  https://t.co/9h1SvsKV8H  https://t.co/YyAz2wH6rJ

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin announced yesterday that free guided tours of the State House grounds will be available for visitors while the building remains closed to the public.  Large groups are encouraged to call ahead.  https://t.co/RkfUA4q3uM  https://t.co/Ofx22MNEOm

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @PL_Coll Voters who are incarcerated can already vote in Massachusetts, as long as they haven't yet been convicted of a felony.  Secretary Galvin has filed a bill to make voting by mail permanent, but it hasn't been passed by the Legislature yet.  https://t.co/sKcWsU46dN

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Don't forget that the Commonwealth Museum has special weekend hours tomorrow for Juneteenth.  Come by 9am-4pm. Parking & admission are free!

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Happy Bunker Hill Day, Suffolk County!  It's a big week for holidays in Massachusetts. We began the week with Flag Day and we will end it with Juneteenth celebrations.  https://t.co/6pJ4y7tSqN

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: Secretary Galvin opened the @MassMuseum special Juneteenth exhibit today. The exhibit will be open to all, for free, through 4pm Saturday.  https://t.co/4OsP4GFE2i  https://t.co/vVPnz3yVae

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @MassMuseum This Juneteenth exhibit features original documents from the Massachusetts Archives, including:  -The 1st law regulating slavery in British North America -A census of enslaved persons -An Act ratifying the 13th Amendment  & more:  https://t.co/iZD0JITSut

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: A special @MassMuseum exhibit, "Juneteenth: Enslavement to Emancipation," opens tomorrow.  The museum will be open on Saturday from 9am-4pm so you can see the exhibit on Juneteenth.  https://t.co/iZD0JITSut

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: A reminder that the law allowing voting by mail is set to expire June 30.  Sec. Galvin has asked for an extension through the end of the year & has filed a bill to make voting by mail a permanent option.

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: @racerben While our office doesn't administer that particular law, we're happy to try to get you to the right office. Perhaps @Mass_Consumer would be able to help you with that question?

name: Mass Secretary of State
tweet: SEC Chairman Gensler is testifying now on important securities issues, including gamification and payment for order flow.
